Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: An emergency diversion cuts across three sectors at once, requiring rapid multi-sector coordination.
Story: I was hunched over my radar screen, headset pressed tight, my mind racing as an emergency diversion cut across three sectors. My supervisor’s voice crackled in my ear, “We need you to coordinate with North and West, now.” My hands flew over the console, relaying instructions, every second critical to the safety of hundreds in the air. Suddenly, out of the corner of my eye, through the glass wall of the break room, I saw my younger brother outside, phone in hand, stepping off the curb without looking. My heart lurched. I was supposed to look out for him—Mom’s words echoed in my mind, “Always keep an eye on your brother.” But the radio blared again, “We’re losing separation!” I felt split in two, tethered by the weight of both worlds, each demanding my full attention, each with lives at stake. My breath caught as I realized I couldn’t be everywhere at once.
